text: [Music]
hello and welcome to practical defenses against aboriginal machine learning i'm your host ariel herbert voss
who am i i'm a research scientist at openai i'm also a phd student at harvard university
and most of my work involves breaking machine learning systems that are deployed in real world contexts so this means that i look at the usual
suspects like malware classification and image recognition but it also means that i look at things like analytics platforms
recommendation systems fraud detection financial trading bots et cetera so basically anything that
relies on machine learning as a course offer component i look at and the content of this talk
is mostly the work has mostly been done in my capacity as a phd student for a book that i'm writing for no starch
press so what is this talk well 30 of it is me recounting experience and attempting
to replicate attacks that have gotten the most press coverage um spoiler this means that uh every show
machine learning in the real world is wildly different from academic research surprise
a lot of academic research around aboriginal machine learning tends to focus on things like aboriginal examples which are extremely interesting and
important as methods for probing our understanding of the dynamics of how machine learning systems work
but they tend to take up a bit too much error in the security conversation because they don't actually constitute a
security threat beyond being yet another method for generating data points which the model will mathematically misclassify
there exists other methods for doing this that are much cheaper and require much less math and are therefore much more attractive
the next 30 percent of this talk is going to be examples of attacks that i've seen in the wild in the last five years or so
the spoiler here is that facial recognition and malware classification are commonly cited but there are more examples of
financially motivated attacks against recommendation systems
the last 40 of this talk is going to be practical advice for defending machine learning systems and this advice
comes down to three recommendations that are centered on avoiding model leakage and bad inputs
so what is wrong with aboriginal machine learning well most attacks that are proposed in the machine learning research literature don't actually work
in the real world and this is for a number of reasons one of the big reasons is that university
and research clusters tend to be different from deployment clusters if you're working in a university environment oftentimes you're going to
do some sort of roll your own cluster adventure with using slurm and mpi you get to work with some byzantine
university i.t infrastructure and your focus is you want to be able to demonstrate mathematically novel attacks
and that's going to be more important to you than things like reliability so features that you'd find in an
industry environment like managed cloud providers containerization continuous integration those kind of things those are all going
to be more of a second thought for you this additional layer of infrastructure that you find in industry
changes the attack surface pretty significantly and as such it makes it really hard for literature around aboriginal machine
learning to apply itself to um real world situations
another thing is that the artificial constraints that people kind of set up around developing these kind of novel attacks
in in the literature they make it really hard to actually say anything about these attacks in the real world it's possible
to say something scientific about these kind of attacks which is really important from a research standpoint but realistically most attackers don't
really have constraints they're not going to really limit themselves to a tiny epsilon ball around the decision boundary
they're going to do whatever gets the job done fastest and they're going to do with the least amount of pain so ultimately this means that
gradient-based attacks constitute um a much less much smaller percentage compared to other less mathy and quick
and dirty attacks so roughly about 15 of attacks that are seen in the wild tend to be these gradient-based
average show example kind of attacks and so we're going to look at some of these less mathy quick and dirty attacks as part of this talk um and i want to
emphasize that these attacks are clever but they're not necessarily complicated at least in the theoretical sense they require a basic understanding of
how machine learning works but they don't require specific knowledge of algorithms or models or any sort of specific
areas of esoteric math we can also distill these down to two types of exploits where you
have bad inputs and you have model leakage so a sexy advantage example of bad
inputs is with self-driving cars uh so last year i had a talk at defcon where i took some salt and they poured
it on the ground because it was cold and it was in boston and i drove my friends tesla and lo and behold the tesla started driving
off into into the sunset when it should not have been doing that and then 10 cent keen lab came out with
a very similar report where they showed if you stick stickers on the ground uh the tessa will also interpret these
stickers as a line and it'll eat off into the sunset as well should not do that
but it's very cool that it does there's no need to generate any sort of bespoke adversarial examples for this kind of
attack you literally are just creating a physical artifact in the real world sticking it out there
and the autopilot algorithm is interpreting it as part of the environment and then
behaving accordingly so it's the perfect example of bad inputs i will say as a caveat we have not seen
this kind of attack in the wild but the fact that we have done it on a real system that exists in the wild means that it is something that should
be considered as like a reasonable example
an example of model leakage is with malware classifiers with the scilance endpoint protection bypass that
skylight cyber had last year where they showed that you can append a bunch of carefully selected strings to a malicious file
and then fool the classifier into marking that file as benign this required some reverse engineer to
identify how the featurizer processes strings and then identifying which strings the model responds to best
so i'd say that model leakage kind of comes down to sharing too much information about the model to the point where somebody can either
reverse engineer how it works or as we'll see in the next tech steal its functionality and use that to build bad inputs bad inputs and model
leakage kind of go hand in hand together much like fuzzing and reverse engineering in other software security contacts it's
kind of turtles all the way down i'd say so for this other model leakage attack
um the a really good example here is the email filters with that fantastic cbe in the proof point email protection
which was maybe not so fantastic for the people who had to fix it this one is really cool because uh the
researchers collected scores from proof point email headers and then they built a surrogate model of the classifier that proofpoint uses
to identify phishing emails and then from there um they were able to use the surrogate model to then crash malicious emails
that will receive preferable scores and this is very similar in the spirit of the previous one
um but in this case you're doing more um you're doing more of like a a surrogate kind of model theft attack
than you are doing um like your reverse engineering kind of attack but they both kind of fall under the
umbrella model leakage because they both require um the person who built the system to
have left out some information for you to pick up and use to reverse engineer or
build something new for malicious use
another example of bad inputs is with transportation prediction algorithms this is a really great one uh this
there's this artist in germany who had this wagon full of 99 smartphones that were running google
maps and ended up causing a traffic jam um because the congestion algorithm that google maps uses to predict whether or
not there's going to be a traffic jam um it treats each one of these phones as a discrete car object
and so if you have a whole bunch of them just sit in a pile and wagon it's just going to interpret that as a giant massive
pile up and then people are going to respond to this notification on their map um accordingly and then it's going to
cause like a bigger issue and you're going to get a jam out of that so it's a really great kind of artsy example of a bad input kind of attack
it's it's non-traditional because it wasn't malicious it was more just like a thought-provoking piece but it's still
like a really good example of some of the vulnerabilities that you find in these kind of systems that you might not have expected
and there could be i could imagine a scenario in which somebody would want to do something very similar with a very similar
type of system yeah
another really great example of bad inputs is with recommendation engines recommendation engines have been around
for a very long time like you've got amazon i'd say google kind of counts as a recommendation algorithm because it's recommending you search results
as long as these kind of products have been around black hat seo has been around and that's all about trying to
use things like click farms and review farming depending on if you're like yelp or amazon to try to pump up your product or
your link or whatever it is when the algorithm is trying to down rank you and it's very much a cat and
mouse game it's been played for a long time i'm not going to go too much into the details there and if you're in the
industry like you're already probably pretty aware of this wonderful cat and mouse game
but it's it's a really good example of bad inputs and some of the harms that come about from
not thinking too clearly about where you're getting data from i guess a contemporary example of this
is during this um coronavirus outbreak i've been doing a lot of jigsaw puzzles and i found this one jigsaw puzzle that
was on um it was on amazon and it was of the i forget actually what it was of i think it was
it was the baby baby yoda um and it was definitely a chinese knock-off and i was very excited because it was very cheap
um but when the puzzle actually came in and it also had really good reviews and i was still kind of sketched out by
it because it just didn't look that legit and the reviews were all kind of the same copy-pasted thing over and over again um and i get the puzzle in the mail and
i open it up and like half of the pieces are missing the backing is just a total mess and then trying to
report it and send it back to them it was just just kind of a huge hassle but it's really a great visceral example of
how recommendation engines and bad inputs are something that we still kind of face today as like a kind of low level attack
kind of situation another example of bad inputs um is with trading bots so i had this
project a few years ago where i was called in for this um this they were trading about cryptocurrency
startup um they had these bots that would they'd pull in information from twitter and some of these financial
crypto forums and they would use that information to make predictions about what the price is going to be and then they would make trades based off of
those predictions and they called me in because they were noticing that there were some weird behaviors about the prices they noticed
that they were kind of changing in a very regular way that just doesn't seem realistic um so we did some
digging and we found out that somebody some people were kind of flooding the hashtags that
this bot was using in its sentiment analysis engine to convince the algorithm that the price
needed to go up because people were talking very positively about this cryptocurrency coin which is now no
longer with us for good reason probably um so this is another great example of bad inputs
because they weren't sanitizing anything they were just kind of pulling straight from twitter and they weren't really thinking through what could your threat model be around
somebody who might want to make money off of your poor bot design
another example is with fraud detection of model leakage specifically if you work in fraud detection
like you know this space but my favorite example of this is
there was this attack i want to say it was like two years ago where there's this group that they made
a bunch of fake apps that weren't monetized and they deployed them on the android store and they were just like very basic apps you
just click through and just push a bunch of stuff and the whole point of this app is they're just collecting kind of how you're scrolling through
stuff and how you're clicking on things and timing and whatnot and the whole point of this is
to sort of train a secondary model that can approximate that kind of behavior and then the idea is you then deploy
that model on a set of ad monetized apps so that way you don't need to sort of do content or user farming if
you're running some sort of scheme like this you can just literally run this model and it will generate revenue for you and you don't have to do that much work
it ended up getting detected it was phenomenal but it was a really good example of model leakage because in order to
execute this kind of thing you need to have some idea of how the android store or whatever app store you're using does like
some sort of bypass or does its um its ad fraud detection and most of these
things they all use machine learning because everybody loves machine learning for um like detecting this kind of stuff
because it's usually like a pretty good like first pass for um if there's something that should be flagged
so um that was a whirlwind tour of seven different kind of attacks that we've seen within the last five years
um they're not as sexy as you might expect but they definitely still count as attacks um machine learning is something that's
very popular these days because it's something that people seem to think is going to give you a lot of business revenue um that may or may not be true depending
on what industry you're in i'd say that like depending on your industry um you could probably make a decent amount
of money there's probably other situations in which you don't necessarily need machine learning but all that to be said
the more popular that machine learning gets as a tool to use for business analytics the more popular it gets
to be a target for people to focus on trying to make money off of the exploitation
of these kind of systems so i have here a list of three defenses more or less
that will cut down on like issues that you will have by about 85 which is pretty cool so the first one is
you should use block lists so the example that i shared about the trading bot is the way that we fixed that issue and we were able to fix it like 100 we
just used an allow list for information sources so we didn't just pull from random we pulled from a couple of different
things and there was human in the loop whose role it was is to make sure that things are moving slowly
i think a very important part of developing a machine learning system that is robust to issues with
bad inputs is to make sure that you at least have some sort of human in the loop kind of interaction because that lessens the chance that
you're going to find something or that you're not going to it lessens the chance that you're going to miss something important because at
least you have human reasoning ability around these very nascent ai systems that are not quite not quite ready yet to be out
on their own doing this detection work so the second defense here is you want
to verify the data accuracy using multiple signals so an example is for a facial
recognition system um we saw a 75 reduction in average show example induced false positives
when we use two camera sources instead of one for identification this percentage increases when you have
when the two cameras are farther apart so if if you're familiar with byzantine fault tolerance and distributed systems
this makes sense because if you have multiple sensor sources or like multiple nodes um it's harder for a malicious or faulty
sensor oftentimes you can't tell the difference um to fool the consensus algorithm into accepting a bad decision
and this is especially self-evident in self-driving cars which tend to use a decent amount of sensors so that if one of them ends up either breaking
or if it's getting bad input at least you have a couple of other ones you can rely on and they'll all kind of communicate and
sort of decide what the reality outside of the car is like
so the third defense is you want to resist the urge to expose raw user statistics or raw statistics to users there is
always going to be a trade-off between providing interpretable predictions and providing enough information that an attacker could reverse engineer your
model there's a lot of conversation around the importance of having interpretable predictions because
it's understandable you have this black box model you kind of want to understand what it's even doing but at the same time if
you give too much information about what it's doing it makes it really easy for people to figure out like okay
given that it's responding to these pieces of information with these numbers i can probably pump up these numbers
for this other piece of information using this extra thing so it's it then becomes kind of its own attack
vector in its own right so um one of the most surefire ways of
handling this because it is a trade-off you can't really get rid of is you want to round your statistics this tends to reduce
the ability to reverse engineer models that are deployed on certain cloud api services by about 60
based off of some research that's been done by me
so um in conclusion of all of this um the methods of exploitation for ml
systems are very similar to traditional software um in practice we see two categories of
exploitation we see the bad inputs examples with self-driving car stuff with transportation prediction trading bots
recommendation engines and on the other side we have model leakage which really tracks with the malware
classification example email filters and fraud detection
there's a lot of taxonomies for categorizing potential attacks but in practice we tend to just see these two categories
which is pretty interesting and as i mentioned earlier bad inputs and information leakage
tend to enable um like model reverse engineering and also like building surrogate models so that
you can do bad things with it and not only could you do bad things with it but you could also um
use that to kind of steal somebody else's ip which is problematic if you have some sort of proprietary solution that
like is your workhorse for your company which is you want to protect that so you want to make sure that you're not giving out too
much information so that somebody can reverse engineer it
so based on what we've seen in the wild and our own experiments about 85 of attacks on ml systems can be
mitigated with these three recommendations which i will reiterate again you should use a block list
you should verify the data accuracy using multiple signals and you should resist the urge to expose raw
statistics to users and that is what i have for you please reach out if you have questions
or if you hated this or if you have feedback or if you want to know more my dms on twitter are open i'm at
adversarial and you can also send me an email at adversarial openai.com so thank you
